request-90.tweet: Tomorrow is bottling day for the Dubbel and I want to put some of that into champagne bottles.I'm doing a dry run today with some soda water and plastic corks. Looks good so far 🙂 #homebrewing #Dubbel

request-91.tweet: I was a bit worried this morning when I could not see any activity in the airlock. Raising the fermentation temperature to 20°C seems to do the trick, right now I have a happy fermentation and some beautiful Kräusen. And if the scent of fresh plum cake coming from the fermenter is any indication, this is going to be a delicious beer. Seriously, the yeast notes and the aroma of dark fruit smell like they're coming directly from my mother's oven! 😋 #homebrewing #dubbel

request-92.tweet: Nailed the original gravity. I aimed for 15°P and ended up slightly north of that. I guess this will lead to a 6.9% ABV beer. Perfect!And look at that color! 😻Now if you'll excuse me, I have a terrible mess to clean up.

request-93.tweet: I got the beer in the fermenter and inoculated with Lallemand Abbayé. I'm exploring the lower end of its temperature spectrum this time. At 22°C, it threw out some perfumy-solventy notes that are all right in a Blond but not great in a Dubbel. Instead, I ferment this at 19°C. Lallemand says that the yeast will produce "darker fruit aromas and flavors of raisin, date and fig" which sounds terrific for a Dubbel 😍 Oh and of course I'll ferment this open as soon as I get Kräusen.

request-94.tweet: I added the rock candy sugar at the 35 minute mark. Got this from our local tea store and I am not sure if this is much darker than the supermarket stuff. But hey, support local businesses, right?The candi sugar is supposed to give the beer more color and nice candy sugar notes. It's not the same thing as this candi sugar syrup stuff but I refuse to import ingredients from the US when some rock candi sugar for 3,95 gets me close enough.

request-95.tweet: Even if everything else goes south and I get terrible beer from this, I can still just look at the beer and be happy about the color which I find absolutely gorgeous! 😻

request-96.tweet: I have decided to use Hallertauer Tradition for this beer exclusively. Its delicate and more traditional floral aroma and flavor probably work better than any of the more IPA-centric varieties that I have in stock.I plan to use a sizeable (for a Dubbel) quantity for bitterness and flavor charges (40g each). I have sampled a couple of Belgian Beers recently and some of the best had quite some hop character that contributed positively to the overall flavor. I want that for my Dubbel.

request-97.tweet: Got some benedictine monk chants playing on the speaker and the malt mashed in at 63°C. I'll keep it there for 30 minutes and raise the temperature to 70°C for another 30 minutes. This Hochkurz-style mash worked well for my Enkel and got me a good head retention and body without any protein rest at like 50°C, so I guess I can skip it in the future. This time I'll follow the advice from John Palmer's "How To Brew" and raise the temperature of the first rest to 63°C instead of 60 for better yield.

request-98.tweet: Oh yes, the ratios:* 85% Pilsner Malt* 4% Special W Malt* 1% Carafa 2 Special Malt* 10% Dark rock candy sugar (added at the boil)I'm going easy on the specialty malts for a while now and I think it really makes my beers better, so 5% is what I feel comfortable with for a Dubbel. The rock candy sugar will also add plenty of character, so no need to go overboard here. This should result in a nice and dry beer in the end.Also taping the recipe to the cupboard is super convenient.

request-99.tweet: I'm back with scale batteries and a second breakfast, so it's time to move on with the grain bill.I always thought that Westmalle nailed the balance between some dark fruit caramelyness and a touch of roast, so I base my grain bill on theirs. Stan Hieronymus' book "Brew like a monk" lists "Pilsner, caramel and dark malt" as well as "dark candi sugar". For me this translates to Pilsner Malt, Weyermann Special W and Carafa 2 Special.

request-100.tweet: Today is brewday!I took the day off to make a Dubbel. I've been at it since 7:30 to finish it in reasonable time. This is one of my favorite beer styles and I am super excited about this. :blobcheerbounce: And yes, this is a 🧵 #homebrewing #dubbel

request-101.tweet: The Wall of Fame above my Ferminator is coming along nicely 🤗 Three Belgian Trappist Abbeys down, two to go 🙂 #homebrewing

request-102.tweet: Guess where I have been for a long weekend full of getting inspiration for future homebrews... 🙂The Caracole Ambrée was excellent by the way. Raisiny-malty and with a solid 8.8% ABV punch that made me sleep well. Reminded me of my Bière de Garde but with a less crazy yeast. Our friend fell in love with their Blonde Ale "Saxo" and this brewery with its wood-fired kettles is already on our itinerary for the next time.

request-103.tweet: It's finally cool enough for this timeless classic 😍 This is a perfect autumn beer for me: Dark, complex, rummy-raisiny, dry and with a nice 7% ABV punch that you don't taste at all. Lovely.And way hoppier than I remember. Joe Stange was right, there's quite some hop character in this.#dubbel #beer

request-104.tweet: My first bottle bomb in eight years of homebrewing. Yay, I guess?Entirely my own fault. I thought "Eh, there is no significant amount of sugar left in that beer, the fermentation is complete, let's bottle this" and the diastaticus yeast gave me a little lesson in humility.I'm fine. But if you brew and bottle: Don't be dumb and arrogant like me. Make sure that primary fermentation is really finished before bottling#homebrewing

request-105.tweet: The Belgian Blond hit 2.ish °P. Looks like I'm bottling tomorrow.And from what I can tell about the Jungbier I finally got the honey melon character of the Hüll Melon right 😍 The flavor starts off with some typical Belgian clove-and-banana thing and then drifts off to honey melon.This is going to be a very silly beer.I love it!#homebrewing

request-106.tweet: And we have some Kräusen. Not a lot though and judging by the airlock activity, the fermentation is not as active as it would have been with yeast nutrients. I guess this was to be expected. But I am not in a hurry, if this finishes a few days later than usual, that's not a problem.There's also very little brown gunk to scoop off. Apparently I get better at keeping trub and hop resins in the brewing kettle 🥳 #homebrewing #openFermentation

request-107.tweet: Aww maan, I got better at mashing again. 16°P instead of 15. Which means that I get a 7.3% ABV. beer (assuming an FG of 2.5°P).Welp. It's not going to be pintable but it's going to be beautifully strong. Works for me too.Now for the cleanup. Yay...

request-108.tweet: I fermented the beer at 21°C last time but with the Ferminator, I feel cocky. I'll try 22°C this time!I am unsure how fast Abbayé is going to work without the extra yeast nutrients but I guess that I can open the fermenter tomorrow morning and switch to an open fermentation as long as I have Kräusen.

request-109.tweet: The wort is in the fermenter and inoculated with Lallemand Abbayé now. Abbayé is a pretty versatile yeast with a surprising complexity. In my Enkel, it mostly added nice clove-like phenolics, in the more sugar-heavy Tripel it brought some fruityness (pear and banana) into the mix. I guess the Blond will probably go down the Tripel road due to its high gravity. Anyway, this yeast is the star of the beer and I'm excited to see what artsy nonsense it will give me this time 🙂
